section.title: Minor Scales
section.p: There are three minor scales: the natural minor scale, the harmonic minor scale, and the melodic minor scale. Play or sing through each one and notice the differences.

image.description: The major, natural minor, harmonic minor, and melodic minor scales all starting on C, noting that the natural minor has lowered 3rd, 6th and 7th scale degrees, the harmonic minor has lowered 3rd and 6th scale degrees, and the ascending melodic minor scale as a lowered 3rd scale degree

section.p: The melodic minor scale has an ascending version, shown above, and a descending version that is the same as the natural minor scale.

image.description: The ascending melodic minor scale on C has a lowered 3rd scale degree and the descending version has lowered 3rd, 6th, and 7th scale degrees

section.p: So far, we have looked at minor scales in relation to the major scale. However, we will typically encounter minor scales in music using minor key signatures.

section.title: Minor Key Signatures
section.p: Minor key signatures agree with the notes of the natural minor scale. Since the natural minor scale had , , and , the key signature of C minor has three flats, written in the order of flats, , .

image.description: An example showing the lowered 3rd, 6th, and 7th scale degrees placed after the clef as the key signature for the minor key

section.p: Therefore, a minor key signature will have three lowered notesthe 3rd, 6th, and 7thin relation to the corresponding major key signature. We use the term parallel minorparallel minorminorparallel when referring to a minor scale that has the same 1st scale degree (in this case ) as the major. We say, The parallel minor of major is minor, and The parallel major of minor is major. One method of figuring out a minor key signature is to add three flats to the parallel major key signature. This is the same as subtracting three sharps.

image.description: Adding 3 flats or subtracting 3 sharps to get to the parallel minor key signature from the major key

section.p: Note on uppercase versus lowercase: When writing below the five-line staff to designate keys, we will use the shorthand of upper case for major () and lowercase for minor (). When writing prose, we will use uppercase: C major and C minor.

We use the term relative minorrelative minorminorrelative when referring to a minor key that has the same key signature as a major key. For example, the relative minor of major is minor because both have three flats in the key signature. Conversely, one could say the relative major of minor is major. The relative major is three half steps above the relative minor.

section.p: Compositions in minor typically do not strictly use only one of the three minor scales, however. The three minor scales are distillations of composers’ actual practice.

section.title: Scale Degree Names
section.p: scale degree namesScale degrees, though often referred to by numbers, also have names.

image.description: For scale degree names, 1 is "tonic," 2 is "supertonic," 3 is "mediant," 4 is "subdominant," 5 is "dominant," 6 is "submediant," and 7 is "leading tone"

section.p: These names will be used throughout this text to refer to scale degrees, chords built on these scale degrees, and keys associated with these scale degrees.
Another way to understand why some scale degrees have “sub-” in their names is through the following example.

image.description: An example showing that the dominant is a 5th above tonic and the mediant is midway between them, and that the subdominant is a 5th below the tonic and that the submediant is midway between tonic and subdominant

section.p: Notice that the subtonic is a whole step below the tonic, while the leading tone is only a half step below the tonic.
